Toyota Sequoia ranks as big SUV.

Once so wary of a potential buy-American backlash that it postponed the debut of a full-size pickup truck, Toyota now seems determined to butt heads with Ford and General Motors on the front line of nearly every truck segment.

Among its more recent new truck entries is the Sequoia sport utility vehicle. Nearly a foot longer and a couple of inches wider than its SUV flagship Land Cruiser, Toyota Sequoia is roughly the size of Ford's Expedition. Although larger than Land Cruiser, it is priced about $10,000 less.

Bolted together in Indiana, Sequoia gives Toyota entry into the mainstream full-size SUV market. It is aimed at the customer currently buying Chevy Tahoes, GMC Yukons and Expeditions. Sharing its platform with the Tundra pickup, Toyota Sequoia enjoys almost 11 inches of ground clearance - a segment best. It is configured with either two-wheel or four-wheel drive, and is offered in two trim levels: the SR5 and higher-end Limited. My test Sequoia was a Limited 4x4.

While they share a platform, front-end components and their V-8, Toyota Tundra and Toyota Sequoia are not the same vehicle with different bodies. Unlike Tundra, Sequoia's frame is fully boxed, the front independent suspension has been tweaked and a five-link coiled spring rear suspension replaces Tundra's leaf spring architecture. The end result is a quieter, less harsh ride.

Moreover, the V-8 has been modified, requalifying it as an ultra-low-emission-vehicle from the low-emission-vehicle rating of Tundra. Although the V-8 gives up five horsepower in Toyota Sequoia, its numbers are still healthy at 240 horsepower and 315 foot-pounds of torque. It is capable of towing 6,200 pounds when fitted with 4WD. It gains 300 pounds of towing capacity with just rear-wheel drive. A four-speed automatic transmission passes engine output to the wheels. Shifting from RWD to 4WD-high is accomplished with a push of a button on the dashboard.

Tipping the scale at 5,300 pounds, the 4x4 Sequoia still manages to reach 60 miles per hour from a stop in just over 10 seconds. As might be expected, fuel economy isn't a selling point. The Environmental Protection Agency rates the 4x4 Sequoia's miles per gallon at 14 in the city and 17 on the highway.

Toyota Sequoia is a truck and a big truck at that. Its ride, however, is calm over smooth surfaces. Rougher roads or no roads make things a bit livelier. Disc brakes are fitted to all four wheels. An anti-lock system is standard. Also standard are Vehicle Skid Control (VSC), and Traction Control (TRAC) or Active Traction Control (A-TRAC). VSC minimizes loss of control when cornering, while TRAC (2WD) and A-TRAC (4WD) minimizes loss of traction on slippery surfaces.

Sequoia's cabin is expansive. With seating for up to eight, it is as adept at transporting people as it is at hauling stuff. All seating positions have three-point seat belts. The 50/50 split rear seat not only folds and tumbles, it slides forward or back to accommodate longer legs or extra cargo. All controls and switches are neatly arranged.

Everything is easy to find and uncommonly simple to operate. There are 10 cup holders, six storage pockets and four 12-volt power outlets. The Limited comes with a 10-speaker JBL audio system, dual front/rear air conditioning system and leather interior.

Sequoia's height makes getting in and out a bit of a challenge, but the standard running boards solve the problem. Access to the rear cargo area is achieved by lifting the rear hatch or lowering the power rear window. Incidentally, the rear window will lower completely into the rear hatch.

Big, powerful and Toyota dependable, the Sequoia won't be a wallflower in the full-size SUV segment. And, with Sequoia being the biggest of trees, you have to wonder if it will also be the biggest of Toyota SUVs.

Base price of the Toyota Sequoia Limited 4x4 is $42,275. Standard features not already described include alloy wheels, dual front air bags, dual heated power retractable outboard mirrors, fog lamps, front captain's chairs, power windows and door locks, tilt steering wheel, cruise control, auto on/off headlamps, center console and automatic climate control. Adding the $495 delivery charge brought the final total to $42,770.

Heaps, Russ
The Washington Times
April 13, 2001
